column1: Nathan Hale (June 6
column3: 1776) was an American soldier and spy for the Continental Army during the American Revolutionary War. He volunteered for an intelligence-gathering mission in New York City but was captured by the British and executed. Hale has long been considered an American hero and
column5: he was officially designated the state hero of Connecticut.

column1: == American Revolutionary War ==
After the Revolutionary War began in 1775
column2: Hale joined a Connecticut militia unit and was elected first lieutenant within five months. His company participated in the Siege of Boston
column3: but Hale remained behind. It has been suggested that he was unsure as to whether he wanted to fight
column4: or possibly that he was hindered because his teaching contract in New London did not expire until several months later
column5: in July 1775. On July 4
column7: Hale received a letter from his classmate and friend Benjamin Tallmadge
column8: who had gone to Boston to see the siege for himself. He wrote to Hale
column10: I think the more extensive service would be my choice. Our holy Religion

column15: Hale accepted a commission as first lieutenant in the 7th Connecticut Regiment under Colonel Charles Webb of Stamford.

column1: Hale was also a part of Knowlton's Rangers
column2: the first organized intelligence service organization of the United States of America
column3: led by Lieutenant Colonel Thomas Knowlton. In the spring of 1776
column4: the Continental Army moved to Manhattan to defend New York City against the anticipated British attack. In August
column5: the British soundly defeated the Continentals in the Battle of Long Island via a flanking move from Staten Island across Brooklyn. General George Washington was desperate to determine the location of the imminent British invasion of Manhattan; to that end
column6: Washington called for a spy behind enemy lines
column7: and Hale was the only volunteer.

column1: === Intelligence-gathering mission ===
Hale volunteered on September 8
column3: to go behind enemy lines and report on British troop movements. It was an act of spying that was immediately punishable by death and posed a great risk to Hale. He was ferried across the Long Island Sound to Huntington
column5: on British-controlled Long Island
column6: on September 12. Hale planned to disguise himself as a Dutch schoolteacher looking for work
column7: though he did not travel under an assumed name and reportedly carried with him his Yale diploma bearing his real name.While Hale was undercover
column8: New York City (then the area at the southern tip of Manhattan
column9: mostly south of what is now Chambers Street) fell to British forces on September 15
column10: and Washington was forced to retreat to the island's north in Harlem Heights (what is now Morningside Heights). Shortly after
column12: a quarter of the lower portion of Manhattan burned in the Great New York Fire of 1776. The fire was later widely thought to have been started by American saboteurs in order to keep the city from falling into British hands
column13: and though setting fire to New York during Washington's retreat had indeed been proposed
column14: Washington and the Congress had rejected the idea and denied responsibility for the fire after its outbreak. It has also been speculated that the fire was the work of British soldiers acting without orders. In the fire's aftermath
column15: more than 200 American partisans were detained by the British for questioning.

column1: == Legacy ==
=== Relatives ===
Hale was the great-grandson of Reverend John Hale
column2: an important figure in the Salem witch trials of 1692. Nathan Hale was also the uncle of orator and statesman Edward Everett (the other speaker at Gettysburg) and the grand-uncle of Edward Everett Hale (quoted above)
column3: a Unitarian minister
column5: and activist noted for social causes including abolitionism. He was the uncle of journalist Nathan Hale
column6: who founded the Boston Daily Advertiser and helped establish the North American Review.

column1: === Statues and appearance ===
Statues of Nathan Hale are based on idealized archetypes; no contemporaneous portraits of him have been found. Documents and letters reveal Hale was an informed
column3: detail-oriented man who planned ahead. Of his appearance and demeanor
column4: fellow soldier Lieutenant Elisha Bostwick wrote that Hale had blue eyes
column5: flaxen blond hair
column7: and stood slightly taller than the average height of the time
column8: with mental powers of a sedate mind and pious. Bostwick wrote:

column1: I can now in imagination see his person & hear his voice—his person I should say was a little above the common stature in height
column2: his shoulders of a moderate breadth
column3: his limbs strait & very plump: regular features—very fair skin—blue eyes—flaxen or very light hair which was always kept short—his eyebrows a shade darker than his hair & his voice rather sharp or piercing—his bodily agility was remarkable. I have seen him follow a football and kick it over the tops of the trees in the Bowery at New York
column4: (an exercise which he was fond of)—his mental powers seemed to be above the common sort—his mind of a sedate and sober cast
column5: & he was undoubtedly Pious; for it was remark'd that when any of the soldiers of his company were sick he always visited them & usually Prayed for & with them in their sickness.
